# Introduction {.unnumbered}

*This chapter is under development. Check back soon for the full content.*

## What This Chapter Will Cover

- Limitations of conventional interest-based monetary policy
- Islamic monetary theory and the transmission of monetary policy
- Money supply management without interest rates
- The role of the Islamic central bank
- Reserve requirements and liquidity management
- Open market operations using Shari'ah-compliant instruments
- Inflation and deflation in Islamic economies
- Financing the government budget without riba
- Macroeconomic stability and cyclical management
- Real versus nominal dimensions of monetary policy

::: {.callout-tip title="Key Concept"}
Islamic monetary policy must manage the money supply and price level without relying on interest rates, instead using reserve requirements, open market operations with asset-based instruments, and fiscal-monetary coordination to achieve price stability while ensuring monetary expansion finances productive economic activity rather than speculation.
:::
